org.panther.easybindings

Class EasyBinding

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.panther.easybindings.EasyBinding

  • public class EasyBinding
extends java.lang.Object
    The EasyBinding class provides some key-value binding based on the excellent Cocoa key-value framework.

    Bindings are bidirectional. Objects participating in a value are specified using a key path. All key paths must start with the prefix root, e.g. root.house.door.color.

    Every component in the key path, including the root, must point to an instance implementing the ObservableValue interface, which is used for doing the actual observing. The value encapsulated by the ObservableValue must have a public field with the same name as the path component.

    The last component of the key path must implement the ObservableValue and the WriteableValue interface.

    If one of the intermediate values changed to null, the other value will also be set to null.

    If a value changes, but the other path doesn't fully exists due to a null object, no action will be taken.

    • Constructor Detail

      • EasyBinding

        public EasyBinding(javafx.beans.value.ObservableValue destinationObject,
                   java.lang.String destinationKeyPath,
                   javafx.beans.value.ObservableValue sourceObject,
                   java.lang.String sourceKeyPath,
                   ValueConverter valueConverter)
        Create a new EasyBinding.

        Bindings are (for now) bidirectional. So the destination/source symantics don't actually mean anything.

        See the class description for more information about the parameters.

        Parameters:
        destinationObject - The destination object.
        destinationKeyPath - The destination key path.
        sourceObject - The source object.
        sourceKeyPath - The source key path.
        valueConverter - Used to convert values between binding endpoints. Can be null.

      • EasyBinding

                   java.lang.String destinationKeyPath,

        Bindings are (for now) bidirectional. So the destination/source symantics don't actually mean anything.

        See the class description for more information about the parameters.

        Parameters:
        destinationObject - The destination object.
        destinationKeyPath - The destination key path.
        sourceObject - The source object.
        sourceKeyPath - The source key path.

      • getValueConverter

        public ValueConverter getValueConverter()
        Returns the value converter used for this binding
        Returns:
        the value converter passed to the constructor, or the identity converter if it was null.

      • bind

        public void bind()
        Actually binds the destination key path to the source key path.

        The method will setup listeners for all path components in the destination path except for the last one. If one of them changes, it will stop listening for the old values and start listening for the new values. It will also update the bound value.

        It will also setup listeners for all path components in the source path. If one of them changes, it will stop listening for the old values and start listening for the new values. It will also update the bound value.

      • unbind

        public void unbind()

      • joinKeyPath

        protected static java.lang.String joinKeyPath(java.lang.String[] keyPath)
        Join key path components to a string
        Parameters:
        keyPath - All components of the key path.
        Returns:
        a string containing the path components joined with a dot
